note.body:
@hadess, is there any chance that you can test the AFC backend using the newly added unit tests? You can use the following f41 scratch build: https://koji.fedoraproject.org/koji/taskinfo?taskID=126058117. And the tests can be started e.g. the following way:

```
$ wget https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gvfs/-/raw/wip/oholy/fuse-edit/test/unit/outputstream.c
$ touch config.h
$ gcc outputstream.c `pkg-config --cflags --libs glib-2.0 gio-2.0` -o outputstream
$ gio mount afc://foo # if not auto-mounted 
$ gio mkdir afc://foo/bar
$ ./outputstream afc://foo/bar
```

note.body: So I have finally pushed edit support for SMB, AFC, MTP, AFP, NFS, and SFTP. Those that I identified in https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gvfs/-/issues/249#note_2183412 as easy to implement. It took more time than I expected as it turned out that there were many bugs in the existing codebase. So I pushed also quite a lot of fixes. Before I will take a look at other backends, I would like to merge this. All the backends were tested using the newly added tests except for the AFC backend.

target_title: fuse: Add support for O_WRONLY without O_APPEND or O_TRUNC

note.body: I wrote a bunch of tests to ensure that it wouldn't break existing functionality and that the new functionality would work as intended. It turned out there was a bug in the `_g_file_edit` macro that caused the `append` job to be called instead of `edit`. But there was also a bug in the SMB backend that allowed rewriting existing content even with `append`. So the fact that berg succeeded was just luck…

target_title: gvfs-dav fills entire memory

note.body:
I've started seeing this lately as well. I've tried to run backups with both Déjà Dup and Pika Backup over WebDAV with gvfsd-dav, and the memory slowly gets eaten up until the whole system slows to a crawl. Then eventually the system kills gvfsd-dav, the mount disappears from Nautilus, and the backup fails.

This didn't start happening until a few months ago. Running the exact same backup software over gvfsd-sftp works fine, with gvfsd-sftp never consuming more than 4.1 MB of memory.

I'm on Fedora 40 with Gnome 46.

target_title: Files moving remotely across different filesystems on the same SSH/SFTP server go through the local computer
Support native remote copy operation for SFTP through SSH's IETF standard extension

note.body:
In #652 an additional case of remote-side inter-filesystem movement operation, consisting of remote copy and remote delete operations was discussed. This is just a quick recap of most important info from there so it's not forgotten about. On one hand, #652 extended/superseded this one, but on the other, apparently the move operation should already work when the remote copy is implemented, as nicely explained by @oholy:

> If the move operation is not supported (or failed with the `G_IO_ERROR_NOT_SUPPORTED` error), the copy-and-delete fallback is automatically called (see https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/glib/-/blob/6faed435/gio/gfile.c#L4100-4105). If the copy operation is not supported, the read-and-write fallback is used instead (see https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/glib/-/blob/6faed435/gio/gfile.c#L3770-3772). Moving across different filesystems works as per the issue title, just the data goes through the local system as it uses the read-and-write callback. Once the remote copy is supported resp. once the #35 is fixed, the (remote) copy operation will be automatically used in this scenario instead of the read-and-write fallback.

Also, the remote-side copy is also supported [since OpenSSH 9.0](https://www.openssh.com/txt/release-9.0):

```
 * sftp-server(8): support the "copy-data" extension to allow server-
   side copying of files/data, following the design in
   draft-ietf-secsh-filexfer-extensions-00. bz2948
```

If the copy operation is not supported, the read-and-write fallback is used instead (see https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/glib/-/blob/6faed435/gio/gfile.c#L3770-3772). target_title: Files moving remotely across different filesystems on the same SSH/SFTP server go through the local computer
Files moving remotely across different filesystems on the same SSH/SFTP server go through the local computer

note.body:
This issue is related to #35, but it's not its duplicate!

It covers both #35 and a very common file operation derived from the remote-side copy - the inter-FS file movement, which consists of **two atomic operations: remote copy and remote delete**. In other words, **this issue extends or supersedes #35**, which I failed to mention explicitly in the OP.

So, #35 is the core issue, while #652 includes **both** #35 and a common special case of copy+delete. The current situation is:
- #35 has nor the correct description, nor the title, or it should be closed
- #652 was closed prematurely since the merger is still in progress

To finally merge these two after 2+ years, #35 could be extended with every piece of related information from this one, or vice-versa. And **only then** the other one closed.

target_title: Hide mounts under `$HOME` per default

note.body:
The `major:minor` block device numbers are the primary identifiers as found in `/proc/self/mountinfo` and they can be virtual, with no apparent connection to the actual block device.

Anyway, since this is a `gvfs` code, I believe the `should_include()` functions needs to be extended with more context - e.g. `UDisksBlock` or `UDisksFilesystem` interface. There it's possible to find other mount points associated with a particular block device. However subvolume detection is not easy at this point, it would be just another way of a guess. I believe this needs deeper cuts that the currently proposed solution, just don't have a clear idea at the moment.

About showing/hiding subvolumes and snapshot in other apps - it's a complex question and might deserve a separate ticket. There are multiple components involved in the stack and they're not always correct. And I suppose it's not regularly tested for such slightly more complex scenarios either. It's a general problem with filesystems that natively provide some kind of logical volume managements (as mentioned: btrfs, zfs, bcachefs...).

Thanks.

I don't need the whole strace log. The interesting part is indeed the repeating pattern as there is obviously some live lock. The `getdents64(14, ...)` call is a directory enumeration. The preceding `openat(...) = 14` call should contain its path. It is likely the same "/run/media/steffen/FRIENDS_S4_DISC_2A/WHV" path as for the consequent `statx` call that obtains file info or its parent. Is that file somehow special? note.body:
Ah, I see what's going on now. #652 was erronously marked as a duplicate of this bug here, but it is not strictly the case, because #652 specifically mentioned that it works "for the case of moving files **within the same filesystem** at the remote side" (which is what I am observing as well), just not across different filesystems on the remote side (which a friend has also confirmed). I will retitle that one and reopen it to avoid confounding things with the original report here which was about "copy".

As for copying: the [SSH bug report](https://bugzilla.mindrot.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1653) indicates that it has finally been implemented the [IETF standard extension](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-ietf-secsh-filexfer-extensions-00) in 2022, so GVFS could now use that! (related: https://superuser.com/a/1166384)

With that change of situation, I wonder if this is something that would be easy for a newcomer to implement?

target_title: Hide mounts under `$HOME` per default

note.body:
With zfs there aren't any mounted block devices. Every zfs filesystem is somehow a virtual device. Here is an excerpt of my mtab showing some zfs mounts:
```
rpool/arch on / type zfs (rw,relatime,xattr,posixacl,casesensitive)
rpool/arch/home on /home type zfs (rw,relatime,xattr,posixacl,casesensitive)
rpool/arch/home/martin on /home/martin type zfs (rw,relatime,xattr,posixacl,casesensitive)
informo/martin/Bilder on /home/martin/Bilder type zfs (rw,relatime,xattr,posixacl,casesensitive)
informo/martin/Dokumente on /home/martin/Dokumente type zfs (rw,relatime,xattr,posixacl,casesensitive)
informo/martin/Musik on /home/martin/Musik type zfs (rw,relatime,xattr,posixacl,casesensitive)

```

In this case the mounts for `/home/martin/Bilder`, `/home/martin/Dokumente` and `/home/martin/Musik` will be shown. But there isn't any real block device associated to these in any way. So I'm not sure how we could detect which to show. Since there already is some filesystem specific code in place what about hiding just zfs filesystems under `$HOME`? `gvfs` can't mount/unmount zfs filesystems anyway. But I don't know if the mounts can be hidden from the file managers without hiding them from things like `gnome-system-monitor` as well. While I wouldn't mind that, because the space calculations are questionable there anyways, I know that some people do want to see their filesystems there.

I can repro this crash on a clean install in a VM. Here's my steps:
```
dd if=/dev/urandom of=crypt bs=1M count=200
cryptsetup luksFormat --iter-time 100 crypt
udisksctl loop-setup -f crypt
udisksctl unlock -b /dev/loop0  # if GNOME doesn't prompt you to unlock it
sudo mkfs.btrfs /dev/mapper/luks-the-name
```
Then repeatedly mount via `udisksctl loop-setup -f crypt` and unmount via nautilus until it crashes.

Would be perhaps good to detect that a mountpoint in homedir is a subvolume or snapshot and that the master block device is mounted somewhere else. Look at this nasty code in UDisks: https://github.com/storaged-project/udisks/blob/master/src/udisksmountmonitor.c#L504-L553

No idea how mounts and subvolumes are presented for bcachefs, btrfs, zfs and others...

target_title: Hide mounts under `$HOME` per default

note.body:
Sorry, I'm just overly sensitive to API and behavioral changes, especially in case of a general purpose library. What I was trying to advocate is that there might potentially be users relying on such functionality, even though I'm not personally aware of any, and once this is merged, it will suddenly break things. It's not immediately obvious which component caused that, e.g. in case of a bulk system update. There will always be people who would request a change that will break somebody else's use case.

It's a tough decision. Filesystem subvolumes or snapshots tend to create ghost mtab records, we also have various namespace kinds that may duplicate or hide mounts virtually. Then there's a question of user FUSE mounts (see above). It's not always possible to specify custom/pass-through mount options like `x-gvfs-show`, they might get filtered by a kernel driver or fuse. Fstab records are completely separate sort of things, fuse and others may be operating having suid bit set.

target_title: Hide mounts under `$HOME` per default

note.body: There used to be `gvfsd-fuse` by default mounted to `~/.gvfs`, that was later moved to `/run/user/UID/gvfs` by default. People were commonly using FUSE mounts for PTP, MTP, iPods, cameras, media players and also exfat by then. Not sure if that is still the case nowadays. Not every distributions have `/run` or `/var/run` set up by default, not every distribution mount `tmpfs` in there.
